Director Claude Lanzmann asks detailed, mundane questions that build in mind and feeling of experience over the course of many hours. The enormity of the Holocaust slowly accumulates so that the movie becomes much "larger" than the questions that are asked.

But "United 93" does the opposite. It doesn't build to something larger by focusing on mundane details. It removes political and historical context from a dark historic day and shrinks 9/11 down to making its audience live out a hellish last plane ride with ordinary people.

With all context missing in this film, what then does it really say about 9/11, and is there any reason to take this trip with them? Greengrass is such a good filmmaker and has us so devastated that we can't stop shaking long enough to realize the answer to these two important questions are not all that much and no.

This should be required viewing for all who wish to voice opinions on the 'war against terrorism' over cocktails, write letters to editors, march in 'Stop the war' parades, exercise their right to vote. They should ponder the visible and very personal blood, the obvious psychopathy, and the audible reality of the statement that "Someone is at war with us." The passengers of United 93 chose to fight back and we should never forget or rest until we have won the war they so courageously and rightfully responded to.

United 93 was excellent.  It was so terrifying that I actually felt physically ill for a while.  This wasn't because of graphic blood and gore, but because the actors so realistically portrayed what it must have been like to be on that doomed flight.  The calls home to say goodbye were heart-breaking, and the sheer terror of the passengers felt very real to me.  Still, the passengers never gave up and did everything in their power to fight back, right to the horrible end.

The movie never felt like "Hollywood" to me.  There was no character development, no dramatic lines, no fancy speeches.  It was an amazing film that hit hard.

Flight 93 is a reminder that the indomitable American spirit can overcome the destructive forces of apathy, appeasement and pacifism.  These brave Americans have shown me the meaning of courage in the face of death.

"United 93" is brilliant! Paul Greengrass' (who also did "The Bourne Supremacy" (2004), "Bloody Sunday" (2002) (also wrote the screenplay) & the upcoming "The Bourne Ultimatum" (2007) directing & screenplay is brilliant and impressive! This is the best film of the year! The cast of unknowns are impressive. One of the finest films in recent history! This is an accurate portrayal of the events that occurred on 9/11. The music by John Powell (who also recently did "Ice Age: The Meltdown" (2006) & "X-Men: The Last Stand" (2006) & "The Bourne Ultimatum" (2007) is brilliant and impressive! The cinematography by Barry Ackroyd is brilliant and impressive! The film editing by Clare Douglas (who also film edited Greengrass' "Bloody Sunday" (2002) & Christopher Rouse (who also film edited Greengrass' "The Bourne Supremacy" (2004) is brilliant and impressive! The casting by Sig De Miguel (who did the casting to "Just My Luck" (2006), Daniel Hubbard (who also did the casting to Greengrass' "The Bourne Supremacy" (2004), John Hubbard (who also did the casting to Greengrass' "The Bourne Supremacy" (2004), "Bloody Sunday" (2002) and also "The Theory Of Flight" (1998) & "The Da Vinci Code" (2006), Amanda Mackey Johnson (who also did the casting to "Hoot" (2006) & the upcoming "The Good Shepherd" (2006), & Cathy Sandrich (who also did the casting to "Hoot" (2006) & to the upcoming "The Good Shepherd" (2006) is brilliant and impressive! The production design by Dominic Watkins (who also did the production design to Greengrass' "The Bourne Supremacy" (2004) is brilliant and impressive! The art direction by Romek Delmata (who did the art direction on "The Omen" (2006) & Joanna Foley is brilliant and impressive! The costume design by Lorraine Carson, Dinah Collin (who also did the costume design to Greengrass' "The Bourne Supremacy" (2004), "Bloody Sunday" (2002) and also "The Theory Of Flight" (1998), & Liz McGarrity is brilliant and impressive! One of the year's best films! Those who think that they could take the chance of watching this, do it, those who can't, can wait. This is an cinematic, brilliant, masterful and powerful masterpiece! This is just as powerful and brilliant as "The Passion Of The Christ" (2004)!

Even though we all know the ending, this documentary is riveting and suspenseful for two hours straight. It was incredible to see, and shouldn't be missed by anyone, especially those who think that terrorists should be handled as a law enforcement issue. The movie wasn't gruesome, as some people have said. Instead, I found it inspiring to see ordinary Americans take matters in their own hands, even though they knew they were going to die anyway. Don't miss this movie!

Every American, and I mean EVERBODY, should see United 93, NOW!  Not on DVD in front of your TV in your comfortable little den where you can stop or pause and make popcorn or yak on your cell phone.  This movie truly needs to be viewed at a theatre, widescreen, surround sound, etc, to feel the visual and audible impact.  You need to see and share this experience with your fellow Americans.  People today seem to have very short memories of this tragedy or the other extreme; "it's too soon to watch".

Go watch and decide for yourself.  And don't worry about shedding a few tears; when I saw this on opening day, nobody in the theatre held back, including me.

MOVIE: Film, the most powerful form of expression. Paul Greengrass' United 93 was one of the most moving, terrifying, emotional, and profound movie-going experiences in my life. The film tells the tragic tale of flight 93, the only hijacked plane that never made its target. Historical accounts presented through film are a different type of viewing experience in that we the audience know the outcome. When I watch films like Saving Private Ryan, Pearl Harbor, Schindler's List, Platoon, and other historical films I am experiencing these events for the first time. I was born in 1987, so I never lived through a great war, never experienced one firsthand even though my generation is in the middle of one right now. Sepetember 11th affected all of us, whether we lost someone or not. This is the first film that current generations will experience as a recounting of a tragic event that we lived through. We watched the towers fall, the people jump from hundreds of stories above the concrete jungle. Now Paul Greengrass brings an intimate and very real look into the lives of a few strangers who decided not to sit back and stay quiet. The film sets the tone immediately as it opens a beautiful sunny day as people arrive at the airport, talking on their phones, reading the paper, and getting ready for their flights. We never learn the names of any of the people in the movie, and all of the actors were cast as "no name" actors. It was done for the sole reason of not to exploit this event, and to make it seem as realistic as possible. The film uses parallel editing and jumps back and forth to the unfolding events in the plane and the events in the various control rooms of the military and air traffic control. Greengrass' style is shakey documentary style filmmaking, and those who saw The Bourne Supremacy can recall that. This style works to perfection, and creates a sense of chaos and confusion in the control rooms where 50 people are running around trying to comprehend what happened. They turn on CNN to see one of the towers in flames, later they witness the second plane hitting the next tower. Silence falls, and as I sat in my seat I began to tremble with my eyes beginning to water. We jump back to the plane where Greengrass places the camera as if it were the point of view of one of the passangers. All these passengers are strangers to each other, so they are strangers to the audience. The scenes on the airplane are terrifying, and will grip you and shake you at your core. The fear and the terror feels too real, I was so concentrated as I watched this film because it was so captivating and involving, and the only thing I can say to express my feelings is to quote one of the flight attendents on the plane, "I don't want to be here". The film is important, it's important because it brings new light to something so familiar. Is it too soon though? At first I thought so, but I realize now that it's not too soon at all. It still feels like it was yesterday that I watched the towers fall and the cloud of dust engulf New York City, images like that do not fade. So even 20 years from now people would still be saying it's too soon. The film doesn't deal with politics and is all about the courageous people who did the bravest thing any human being could do, and that is sacrifice their lives. Every American needs to see this film, it has to be seen no matter how uncomfortable it will make you feel. I watch movies like Saving Private Ryan to experience the past, in 20 years people my age will be doing the same with United 93. I am writing this review 4 hours after I saw the film, and I am still shaken by it. It feels like it happened all over again, but you know, it was worth it.

ACTING: You won't be able to name any actors in this film, and it was casted like that for a purpose. If I was a WWII veteran and I watched Saving Private Ryan, I would probably say "That's Tom Hanks, he's an actor, he didn't fight in WWII". In this film you can't name any actor, and that makes it all the more real and you end up forgetting that you are watching a movie. The acting is superb, it's what drove the film. It must have been uncomfortable to film some of these scenes, the terror is genuinely real.

BOTTOM LINE: "Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray. Do not go gentle into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light." - Dylan Thomas. I leave you on that note.

...and haven't we, just a little?

It seems that we have once again become complacent about the world that we live in. I think that we all panic a little every time we get on a plane now, but overall we are not as aware as we were on Sept 12.

This is a film that should be seen and a time that should never be forgotten. Kudos to the film makers for taking such a sensitve subject and handling it brilliantly. The documentary style made you feel the chaos both on the plane and on the ground. No one character is the hero. In fact there is no character developement or story here (if you are thinking Jack and Rose forget it). This is real time action. This is not a nailbiting action flick, the first hour moves along pretty slowly. Much like any other normal Tuesday morning would be. The film oes not offer any explanations about why Sept 11 happened, just that it did. See this movie, talk about it, don't forget.

It was Thermopylae. It was the Alamo. It was like nothing that has happened before in human history.

Much of the power of United 93 is the knowledge that while people cannot realistically imagine themselves with the Spartans at Thermopylae or the Texans at the Alamo, just about everyone has flown in an air liner. Everyone seeing this film can imagine themselves among those brave but doomed passengers, fighting with the courage of desperation for the right to get home alive.

Though one knows what must happen in the film, one to the very last finds oneself praying for a different outcome, one in which the passengers seized back the plane and somehow flew it to safety at some nearby air field. But the film is real life, not Hollywood.

Every human being should see this film. It is a testament to the human spirit, of an indomitable desire, even in the face of death, to not go quietly into that good night.

United 93 contains many haunting moments, but one comes of great surprise. At an air traffic command center, the staff stands about, confused over reports of a hijacking. A plane has disappeared from the grid, and they don't know what to make of it. Someone brings CNN up on the large viewing screen, they stand, baffled, at the image of a smoking hole in the north tower of the World Trade Center. Reliving the beginning of the attack, only armed with the knowledge we have now, is shattering in a very unexpected way.

British director Paul Greengrass' has put together a look at 9/11 with a narrow focus, but with searing strength and focus that puts the viewer in the center of the action in a way not seen since Saving Private Ryan's D-Day assault sequence. We already know the terrible outcome, but watch with curiosity and suspense, secretly hoping that perhaps history can change, if just for this one movie. Just because we know it won't doesn't make the final passenger assault any less gripping or heartbreaking.

Shot in the British docu-drama style that severed the Greengrass-directed The Bourne Supremacy so well, the film never once feels like fiction, but an omnipresent insider's view of the action. The plot moves quickly but with great dread, scenes inside air command inter-cut with the doomed flight, where the four hijackers anxiously await their time to strike. On the ground, chaos runs rampant, with hundreds of people frantically trying to coordinate a response, ounces of clarity coming bundled with pounds of confusion.

Many of the air control and military personnel are played not by actors, but by the real people, which some have said augments the authenticity.  I instead offer the argument that the plane sequences seem so realistic, that Greengrass could have effortlessly pulled off the same effect using a cast entirely composed of actors. The film's accuracy stems from its incredible power, not the other way around.

Much has been made about the film's lack of a political stance, but all films are political, whether or not they know it. The hijackers are shown as real people, true, but it seems childish to imagine that evil men don't form relationships, shave, or get nervous. The sympathy rests exclusively with the victims, who each receive as much screen time as they require, and no more. I struggled to hear names and hints of who each passenger was, but the only one I recognized for sure was Jeremy Glick, a judo expert who the film theorizes lead the charge. Most of the passenger dialogue involves planning the attack, or very painfully, final phone calls home.

One shocking moment that has received little press (as of now) comes towards the end, where a German passenger tries to alert the hijackers to the rebellion before being restrained. I researched the incident, but could find nothing to support the event, except that a German man was in fact on the plane. Was Greengrass trying to portray Americans as the people who stand up and fight back against terror, while cowards like the Germans would rather negotiate and surrender? Maybe not, but the argument could certainly be made.

If the takeover of the plane is gruesome, the passenger's assault serves as a moment of bloody catharsis. It would be hard not to feel a small piece of joy as the hijackers panic, terrified that instead of becoming part of a holy missile to destroy the U.S. Capitol Building, they are going to be quite literally torn to pieces by furious passengers. I suspect that after the horrified screams of the passengers, the film's most talked about sound effect will be the sickening crunch of a fire extinguisher caving in a hijacker's skull.

Endlessly talked about in the mainstream press, United 93 interestingly hasn't received as much buzz as it might amongst audiences. Many feel the film comes too soon after 9/11, while others are apprehensive about having to view the event through the eyes of the dead. Is United 93 too soon?

United 93 not only isn't too soon, it hasn't arrived quickly enough. It succeeds at honoring the victims of 9/11 beyond the wildest expectation. Appropriately harrowing and terrifying, it instantly reaches a realm of importance that few films do. To avoid this genuinely relevant and amazing film out of fear would be a disservice to oneself and the memory of those portrayed within. Mark my words, there won't be a more important work of art made for a long time to come.

Director Paul Greengrass (The Bourne Supremacy) had a very difficult job in making this film, especially since the film deals with a shaky topic that is still fresh in everyone's mind.  That being said, Greengrass makes all the right choices, from casting to writing to the exceptional camera work.  Most people know the basic gist of 9/11, but United 93 fills in all of the details and gives a framework and timeline of events, all while still giving the viewer just enough time to really care for the characters.  Now, it probably wasn't that tough to get viewers to care for these people, especially since 9/11 affected every United States citizen in one way or another.  The first half of the film really doesn't even deal with United Flight 93, except for showing a few short clips in between action, just to remind us that they are still there.  The first half deals with the other flights that were hijacked, namely American Airlines Flight 11 and another United flight.  There are a few different locations and traffic control centers in the movie, but the main control station, that is, the one the film spends the most time in, is the one headed by air traffic controller Ben Sliney (playing himself in the first Oscar worthy performance of the year).  The interesting thing about the control centers is that I had no idea what any of these people were saying, mainly because of all of the airline jargon going on.  However, I still knew what was happening.  No one had to tell me what was going on.  In fact, if I didn't know the context of the dialogue, I probably would have no idea of what these people are saying.  The first hour of the film is incredibly tense.  Greengrass wastes no time in getting to the action.  There is a lull after the first hour (for about thirty minutes) where nothing major happens with developing hijackings or United 93, which gave me time to notice Greengrass' camera techniques that I didn't notice before (because of the tension).  It was probably a good thing that Greengrass elevated the tension in the film, because the camera work is so out of control (it reminds me of Tony Scott's Domino) that it gave me a headache.  The cameras never fix upon a certain point for more than three or four seconds which makes it kind of hard for the brain to latch on to anything.  At first, I was kind of annoyed, but after thinking about it, the camera work made the film that much better.  It gives the viewer a chance to feel like he or she is actually in the film.  It gives a sense of urgency and panic felt by everyone in the film.  The headache is nothing compared to the feelings felt by everyone involved on the ground, as well as on United 93.  Greengrass also chose to cast unknown people in the film, another wise decision.  It alieviates some of that connection that goes along with big movie star power.  It's also a lower budget film which gives a sense of authenticity.  This is by no means a negative critique of big budget films, but rather a promotion of smaller films with smaller casts.  If you are interested in a big budget production of 9/11, Oliver Stone is releasing a blockbuster event called World Trade Center starring Nicholas Cage (The Weather Man), Michael Pena (Crash), and Maria Bello (A History of Violence) set to come out later this year.  Paul Greengrass has created a masterpiece, and I should think that this is a film worthy of anyone's top ten (even mine) at the end of this year (although it is still very early and this is no way a guarantee).  United 93 is an amazing story of courage, fueled with tension, anxiety, strong emotion, and filmed with nothing but respect.

I am glad that I did not have high expectations and had not seen any making-of specials (or even a theatrical trailer) of UNITED 93 and had not read any articles about it or reviews of it prior to going to the first screening of the film on its first day of nation-wide release.  I also had never seen a film directed by Paul Greengrass.  I went because like any other American I will never forget September 11, 2001 and was curious to see the first major Hollywood film dealing directly with the events of that day of infamy.  I would see UNITED 93 with an open mind but not expecting it to be such a major artistic achievement since I generally never believe art and mainstream American filmmaking belong in the same sentence, but I was wrong.  I knew from its opening minutes that it was something special.  A film (and a filmmaker) either has "it" or doesn't and Greengrass and UNITED 93 never takes a false step or makes a wrong move from start to finish.

Writer-director Greengrass has made a new kind of film.  There are two kinds of films:  documentary films and fiction films.  UNITED 93 is a wonderful mutation of both.  It was made with a mixture of unknown actors (a brilliant decision - recognizable stars or semi-stars would distract the viewer who would play spot the star and suspend disbelief) and real-life participants in the events of 9/11/01 who portrayed themselves better than any actor could...obviously.  He also wrote and directed the film in a manner that places the viewer in a virtual reality version of the events of that morning.  It is a matter-of-fact style with normal speech rather than obviously-written "movie" dialogue.  Greengrass shot the film using a handheld camera to increase the realistic you-are-there feeling, but not an annoyingly jerky handheld camera style.  However, when the action becomes more violent and chaotic during the takeover of Flight 93 by the terrorists and the charge at the terrorists by a group of male passengers, the camerawork tumbles the viewer into the scenes in a startling fashion.  Greengrass also uses a moving music score sparingly not pounding the viewer with it like a lot of Hollywood filmmakers would have made the mistake of doing.  UNITED 93 is an emotional experience, not a sentimental experience and there is a huge difference between the two - the difference between what a simple movie maker would do and what an artist does.

UNITED 93 is a vastly different film from other recent films that used actual American historic events as backdrops for their fictional stories featuring movie stars in major roles.  TITANIC and SAVING PRIVATE RYAN both recreated unforgettable events in American history quite well but those two films were actually dominated by the routine Hollywood stories they wanted to tell:

TITANIC was about a rich girl-poor boy/opposites attract romance story starring American matinee idol Leonardo DiCaprio and British matinee idol Kate Winslet.

SAVING PRIVATE RYAN was a search and rescue story starring back-to-back Best Actor Oscar-winner Tom Hanks and up-and-coming pretty boy star Matt Damon and a supporting cast playing classic war movie soldier types (aka cliches).

There is no denying that James Cameron recreated the sinking of the Titanic and Steven Spielberg recreated the D-Day invasion with awesome technical skill but that is where the similarities between those films and UNITED 93 end.  Ridley Scott's BLACK HAWK DOWN is more similar to UNITED 93.  The majority of that film is a recreation of the ambush experienced by American troops in Mogadishu done in a brutally realistic and minute-by-minute style much like UNITED 93.  However, the difference is Scott used recognizable actors including Josh Hartnett, Ewan McGregor, and Tom Sizemore.  I think that UNITED 93 has no precedent in the history of American film.  It is a documentary-like fiction film.

Greengrass had the difficult task of making the first major movie specifically about September 11, 2001.  He could have failed miserably and most likely would.  This film was guaranteed to receive a lot of attention and criticism before anyone even saw it.  Americans (especially those directly victimized by the events of that day) AND people of Middle-Eastern descent could be offended by this film.  At the very least, he could have made a bad movie simply in terms of artistic quality.  Actually, Greengrass has made a masterpiece that honors America and does not demonize all Middle-Easterners (only those responsible).  If anyone commits any hate crimes because they hate the cold killers in this film, they are responsible for their own actions, not a filmmaker.  Greengrass simply portrays the events as a neutral observer would see them.  The terrorists did what they did because THEY believed it was what they were supposed to do and the passengers of Flight 93 did what they did because they thought it was what they had to do.  Greengrass uses such a detached style, there is no way he can be accused of pushing American propoganda or of racism.

One of the achievements of UNITED 93 is how well it sustains such a level of suspense when it is telling a story that everyone knows and remembers so well.  It is difficult to make a movie work when everyone who sees it already knows what is going to happen and how it is going to end.  The key is how well the director can keep us in their grip even though we already have that advantage.  I think that because this film is based on a true story of recent times which had a major emotional impact on all of our lives, it is easier to get caught up in the film even though we know what is going to happen.  Plus, unless you have a good knowledge of 9/11/01, Greengrass can still surprise you with a "plot twist" like discovering (along with the characters in the film) that Flight 11 did not crash into the World Trade Center and is still in the air and still poses a threat.  It is the style of his direction and the little details in his script that most impressed me.  Anyone who has ever travelled by airplane in this country (especially if they do it often) can relate to the portrayal of people waiting in the gate area ignoring each other having their individual conversations on their cell phones or ignoring the routine safety instructions that precedes each flight - I loved the series of shots during this scene:  passengers nodding off, looking out the window, or focused on their laptop screen - exactly how it is on an airplane:  nobody pays attention to these speeches (especially pre-9/11/01).  And how cruelly ironic it is when we see the last passenger rush to make it onto Flight 93 on time (he and his luggage getting through security at the last second quite easily back then, of course) and being told by a flight attendant that he "just made it."  And as destiny would have it, this man wearing a University of California hat will be one of the men who bravely (whether true or via speculation of the what happened onboard, we will never know) rushes the terrorists later in the film.  Most of the film's action centers on Flight 93 whether directly or indirectly, the fate of the other planes were all related.  Greengrass crosscuts between Flight 93 itself and the air traffic centers monitoring the flights that day and the headquarters of NORAD, which is accustomed to simulated events, not real events.  It is interesting to hear everyone's disbelief that there would be a hijacking in America - did any of us think that would happen here where we foolishly thought we were immune to such things?  UNITED 93 is also sprinkled with mundane moments of conversations between the flight attendants and between the co-pilots about their plans for the upcoming days.  These wonderful little moments that most filmmakers would not have included make these people and their impending doom that much more poignant.  The preparation by the terrorists for the hijacking (done in great detail), the last calls home to loved ones by the passengers, and the action-packed finale obviously were going to be featured strongly.  It is everything else that Greengrass includes that makes it truly memorable and emotional.

From the solemn opening... through the wonderful use of flight patterns on FAA computer screens and CNN footage from that day... to the horrifying final moments and crash (rather than fade) to black, UNITED 93 is one of the most impressive cinematic experiences of my life.  I think that it is more powerful for being made so soon after 2001 while it is still relatively fresh in our minds, but that it will be just as powerful when our children or grandchildren first experience those events through this film years from now.  It kept my stomach in knots and my hands clenched for two hours, but I still recommend it be seen because even though it is very painful to watch (probably worse than THE PASSION OF THE CHRIST although not as explicitly violent), UNITED 93 ensures that we don't forget the tragedy of 9/11/01 or the positive actions of some of its heroes.  Plus, I believe it is a great work of art.

I saw the movie about an hour ago, it was the second showing for the day, started at 2:25pm. I was told at the box office that the movie would start on time at 2:25pm with no previews. That is unusual and added to the somber mood, it reminded me of when "Schindler's List" was first shown on TV, there were no commercial interruptions, I believe that was a historic first.

The movie was excellent in every way. It was also non-political. People who say that they are not ready to see a movie about 9/11 are probably being honest, but the ones who add that it is too soon to make a movie about 9/11 are somehow emotionally dodging the issue. There is nothing to wait for. My heart was pounding during most of the movie, probably because I knew that what I saw on the screen was mostly true, so it was very hard to tell myself: "it's only a movie." Some people in the audience had to wipe away tears, including me. The scariest thing about the terrorists was that they were disciplined, deadly warriors, driven by deeply held religious convictions (fundamentalist  Islam). They were neither cowards, nor crazy.

David Beamer, father of Todd Beamer, wrote an article in the Wall Street Journal yesterday. He wrote, about the events on flight 93: "This was our first successful counterattack in our homeland in this new global war" [...]. That's how the movie feels, like a counterattack, and that's why to me, it felt uplifting in the end, despite the terrible subject matter.

I just returned from watching "United 93".  With the exception of Mel Gibson's "The Passion of the Christ" I can't remember a movie having such moving effect on me.

The entire film seems to be shot with handheld cameras, and this gives it a documentary-type feel.  In fact, it is almost as if this entire thing was captured on video as it actually happened and put in the movie theaters.  I'm sure that is exactly how director Paul Greengrass wanted it to appear.

When I first heard this movie was coming out, I had a mix of emotions.  I worried that the film would portray the terrorists as being successful Jihadists that had foiled all of America's best defenses.  That was not the case.  I worried that "United 93" would portray President Bush as a man who failed to lead at such an important time in America's history.  That was not the case - he wasn't even in the movie at all, unless I missed it when I had to leave the theater for a few seconds.

"United 93" captures the emotional trauma, the desperate decisions, and the shockingly horrid events that took place on September 11, 2001.  The film is not your classical big Hollywood production.  There are no breathtakingly choreographed, large set scenes.  There is no famous Hollywood hunk in a lead role that you will remember for years to come.  No, this is a movie on fire with raw emotion.  It is a movie that takes you where you know evil seems to have won.  This film shows how brave men and women made sure that it didn't.

I'm glad I made the choice to see this film.  It has made me think about how precious life is.  It has made me wonder how people can ever view innocent people as a target of revenge, no matter where they live, no matter how they live, and no matter what they think about my God and my faith.  This film is a tribute to freedom in that the passengers of "United 93" decided to fight on, knowing full well that they might die while doing so.

The actors in "United 93" kept their performances on real-life mode, with no one actor stealing the show.  That made the film seem like a documentary (I know, I mentioned this above already).  The last few minutes of this movie are so intense that I actually started to dig my fingernails into the theater chair arms while I was watching.  It's that moving!

The movie is also not as bloody or gory as I expected it to be.  I think kids 13 and older will be okay with this film.

So that's my review; one of the most intense and amazing movies ever made.

See ya next review!

This is the only 9-11 drama to account for the series of events in central command and the FAA.  It is also the most detailed in the passengers fight back.  However, it fictionally alters what in reality was the calm resolve and bravery of the passengers and almost completely omits the FAITH of the Americans - which leads to selfless final expressions of LOVE and bravery - while overplaying the "devotion" to a demonic inversion of true faith of the hijackers which leads to cowardice and mass murder.  In that sense it is disgusting.
